title: Recurrent Breast Cyst Requiring Evaluation
setup_script: A 40-year-old woman has recurrent painful cysts in the right breast. Ultrasound now reveals a 2.5 cm complex cyst with internal echoes and septations. She has no family history of cancer.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Take history of cyclical breast pain, hormonal influences, and previous cyst aspirations; perform clinical breast exam.
Order diagnostic mammography and targeted ultrasound to characterize the complex cyst.
Recognize that complex cysts warrant further evaluation due to risk of malignancy; plan for ultrasound-guided aspiration and cytology.
If fluid is clear and cyst resolves, reassure patient; send fluid for cytology if bloody or turbid.
If cyst recurs rapidly or contains solid components, arrange core needle biopsy to exclude intracystic carcinoma or papillary lesion.
Discuss possibility of excisional biopsy if pathology is atypical or if symptoms persist.
Provide education on benign fibrocystic changes and reassure about low cancer risk with simple cysts.
Encourage regular screening mammography appropriate for age and risk factors.
Manage pain with NSAIDs, evening primrose oil, or hormonal modulation if severe.
Monitor cysts with follow-up ultrasound in 6 months if benign features remain.
Address patient anxiety and provide resources for support.
Document findings and communicate with primary care provider for integrated care.

critical_decision_points: Appropriate imaging and recognition of complex cyst requiring further evaluation.
Decision for aspiration versus core biopsy based on cyst characteristics.
Management of recurrent or atypical cysts with excision.
Patient education and reassurance about benign breast changes.
